Problem:
Consider a function \\( u(x, t) \\) describing heat distribution along a rod governed by the heat equation \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = k\\frac{\\partial^2 u}{\\partial x^2} \\) with constant diffusivity k. Investigate the implications of the Fourier transform \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, t) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} u(x, t)e^{-i\\omega x}dx \\) applied to this model.

Can we reconstruct the exact initial condition \\( u(x, 0) \\) from \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, T) \\) knowing it evolved according to the Fourier-transformed heat equation without knowing the exact form of Fourier transform applied at t = 0?
Explanation: Reversing \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, T) \\) to \\( u(x, 0) \\) relies critically on knowledge of the Fourier transform applied at t = 0. Without this, the transformation does not uniquely determine the initial state because multiple initial conditions can lead to similar transformed states over time due to diffusion effects.
